elements.text: . We saw that Ramon’s sister Marisol hung his art on her wall.

I am going to show you some paintings: We will talk about the paintings, and then you will decide which painting you would most like to hang on your wall. Then you will tell us why you like that painting.
As children speak, encourage the others to listen and to use the Make a Connection hand signal if they agree with the speaker. Model.
Show each Picture Card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of each card to extend conversation.
Display the cards and ask one child to come up, hold up the painting he or she likes best, and explain why that would be his or her choice to hang on the wall.
Have the first child return the card and continue with each child in turn.
Which painting did more than one person like best? Which painting did nobody like best?
A different artist painted each one of these paintings. Which painting is most interesting to you? Which one makes you wonder most? Which one most makes you feel an emotion?
Show children Picture Cards two at a time. Ask,
Which one do you find more appealing? Why do you like it?
Display all five Picture Cards and challenge children to take turns ordering them from favorite to least favorite. Encourage children to explain their choices.
Preview any unfamiliar words that might naturally come up during discussion of the paintings. For example, you might want to preview
bridge, woman, cat, fruit, pear, apples, beach, sand, tiger,
If you wish, use sentence frames to help children explain their choices:

If children have trouble listening politely to one another, use a regular routine to bring them back into focus. To prevent additional interruptions, consider using a visual signal such as a red flashlight or a waving flag or banner. Children will soon learn that the signal means they should stop what they are doing and pay attention to the child who is speaking.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
We have been reading about how one young artist learns to be proud of his work.
I have some pictures of people who are feeling proud. After we talk about the pictures, each of you will get to tell a story about one card.
Remind children that they need to watch their classmates as they speak and listen quietly and politely.
Show each Picture Card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of each card to extend conversation.
Allow each child to choose a card. Have them look closely at the card and then tell their classmates a story about what is happening and why the person on the card feels proud.
Ask the group to applaud for each presenter to encourage them to feel proud of their stories.
If you were the person on your card, would you feel proud, too? Why?
Which of these people would you most want to be? Why? How could you do what that person did?
Use sentence frames to help children tell stories about their cards. Frames might include:
Encourage children to tell their stories in complete sentences, using subject, verb, object order. Model this using a sentence frame such as:

For new language learners, rather than having the children tell complex stories, ask simple questions about the people on the cards. Accept answers that are words and phrases, but expand each one into a sentence and have children repeat the sentence.

Even your most expressive children may still have trouble with syntax, agreement, and word choice. Without interrupting the flow of a child’s ideas, try to repeat and model the correct way to structure the sentence in question, saying, for example,
Yes, she climbed to the top of a mountain
in response to a child’s “Her climb a mountain.”
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Give each child a piece of drawing paper and some crayons or colored pencils.
, we saw how Ramon’s drawing became loose and worry-free after he talked to Marisol.
We are going to do some loose, worry-free drawing. I will give you directions, and you will do your best.
Remind children that they should put crayons down and look at you as you describe what they are supposed to do.
Demonstrate how to draw in long, loose lines, using all of the paper.
As I give you directions, use crayons to do as I say.
First, make a long, loose line all the way across your paper.
Next, draw some short lines going up from that line.
Now add some flower shapes at the top of each short line.
Finally, add any colors you want.
Allow children to describe their drawings. Do they look “garden-ish”?
Was it fun to draw in a loose, worry-free way? Do you think you will draw this way again?
How do you think Ramon felt when he was drawing his “ish” drawings?
As you read the directions, model each one and allow children to copy what you do as well as do what you say. Compare your drawing to theirs when you complete the activity.

Ask children to use the loose drawing style you modeled to draw pictures of any of these subjects: a sailboat, a house, a fish, a tree, an imaginary creature. Ask children to describe how they made their drawings.
Use hand signals to illustrate the key words
as you read the directions for the children’s drawings. Allow children to complete each step before you read the next direction.

Getting children to grasp crayons the way you will later want them to grip a pencil is important. Use a small piece of masking tape on the table or desk to keep the drawing paper from sliding. Model holding a crayon and adjust children’s grips as needed. Encourage children to pick up their crayons using just their thumbs and pointer fingers; model doing this and then flipping the crayon to rest correctly against the middle finger in the tripod grasp.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Today we read about some different kinds of art. People made horses out of paint, metal, and clay.
We will look at some cards that show people making art. You need to decide which ones match, based on the actions of the artists.
Have volunteers suggest their own definitions of the verbs
Show each picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of each card to extend conversation.
Mix the cards, and have children choose one. Ask them to find their match by looking at each other’s cards. The children with cards that show the same action should stand together.
Mix the cards and play again.
How is painting different from drawing? How is sculpting different from painting?
Which artwork shown on the cards do you wish you could make? How would you do it?
Show children Picture Cards one at a time. Ask,
Does this show painting, sculpting, or drawing?
Then lay out the cards and ask children to find pairs of cards with action words—verbs—that match.
Have pairs of children place the cards face down and play a game of Concentration, turning two cards up until they find a verb pair. The child with the most pairs wins.
Preview the verbs by having children imitate your exaggerated actions as you demonstrate painting, sculpting, and drawing while saying the words
Then say the verbs in random order and ask children to demonstrate each one before they begin the Match the Verb activity.

Children who have trouble focusing visually may need to work individually with you, looking at the Picture Cards one by one. Alternatively, mounting each card in the center of a colored manila folder may help children focus more easily on the content of the card, as the framing produced by the folder masks distractions.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
